You can either run the notebook using 

Binder or on your local machine.

The simplest way to interact with a Jupyter Notebook is through


Binder, which enables the execution of a


Jupyter Book in the cloud. The details of how this works are not
important for now. All you need to know is how to launch a Pythia
Cookbooks chapter via Binder. Simply navigate your mouse to
the top right corner of the book chapter you are viewing and click
on the rocket ship icon, (see figure below), and be sure to select
“launch Binder”. After a moment you should be presented with a
notebook that you can interact with. I.e. you’ll be able to execute
and even change the example programs. You’ll see that the code cells
have no output at first, until you execute them by pressing
Shift+Enter. Complete details on how to interact with
a live Jupyter notebook are described in 

Getting Started with
Jupyter.

Note, not all Cookbook chapters are executable. If you do not see
the rocket ship icon, such as on this page, you are not viewing an
executable book chapter.

If you are interested in running this material locally on your computer, you will need to follow this workflow:

(Replace “cookbook-example” with the title of your cookbooks)

Clone the https://github.com/ProjectPythia/cookbook-example repository: git clone https://github.com/ProjectPythia/cookbook-example.git

Move into the cookbook-example directorycd cookbook-example

Create and activate your conda environment from the environment.yml fileconda env create -f environment.yml
conda activate cookbook-example

Move into the notebooks directory and start up Jupyterlabcd notebooks/
jupyter lab

In this example, we will first use the get_data() function from xmacis2py to get the data for the March Air Reserves Base ASOS Station (KRIV) for the past 30 days.

We will then find the following:

Mean Maximum Temperature

Median Minimum Temperature

Mode Average Temperature

25th Percentile Minimum Temperature

75th percentile Minimum Temperature

Standard Deviation of Average Temperature

Variance of Average Temperature

Skewness of Maximum Temperature

Kurtosis of Maximum Temperature

Maximum Max Temperature

Minimum Min Temperature

Precipitation Sum

Top 5 Values for Average Temperature Departure

Bottom 5 Values for Average Temperature Departure

Ranking All Values from Top to Bottom for Average Temperature Departure

Precipitation Running Sum

Average Temperature Running Mean

Detrending Average Temperature (Linear)

Detrending Average Temperature (Constant)

Number of Days The Maximum Temperature >= 75 Degrees

Number of Days the Minimum Temperature <= 35 Degrees

Number of Missing Days for Maximum Temperature

Concepts

Importance

Notes

xmACIS2Py

Necessary

xmACIS2Py Documentation

Intro to Pandas

Helpful

Familiarity with dataframes

Time to learn: 30 minutes



---

Data Access Documentation

Get Data
df = get_data('kriv')
df

Analysis Tools Documentation

Period Mean

Period Median

Period Mode

Period Percentile

Period Standard Deviation

Period Variance

Period Skewness

Period Kurtosis

Period Maximum

Period Minimum

Period Sum

Period Rankings

Running Sum

Running Mean

Detrend Data

Number of Missing Days

Number of Days At Or Below Value

Number of Days At Or Above Value

Number of Days Below Value

Number of Days Above Value

Number of Days At Value

mean_max_t = analysis.period_mean(df,
                    'Maximum Temperature',
                    round_value=True,
                    to_nearest=0,
                    data_type='integer')



mean_max_t

median_min_t = analysis.period_median(df,
                    'Minimum Temperature',
                    round_value=True,
                    to_nearest=0,
                    data_type='integer')



median_min_t

mode_avg_t = analysis.period_mode(df,
                    'Average Temperature')



mode_avg_t

p25 = analysis.period_percentile(df,
                                'Minimum Temperature',
                                round_value=True,
                                data_type='integer')



p25

p75 = analysis.period_percentile(df,
                                'Minimum Temperature',
                                round_value=True,
                                data_type='integer',
                                percentile=0.75)



p75

avg_t_sigma = analysis.period_standard_deviation(df,
                                                 'Average Temperature',
                                                 round_value=True,
                                                 to_nearest=1)



avg_t_sigma

max_t_skewness = analysis.period_skewness(df,
                                         'Maximum Temperature')



max_t_skewness

max_t_kurtosis = analysis.period_kurtosis(df,
                                          'Maximum Temperature')



max_t_kurtosis

max_max_t = analysis.period_maximum(df,
                                    'Maximum Temperature',
                                    data_type='integer')



max_max_t

min_min_t = analysis.period_minimum(df,
                                    'Minimum Temperature',
                                    data_type='integer')



min_min_t

total_precipitation = analysis.period_sum(df,
                                          'Precipitation')



total_precipitation

Top 5 Values for Average Temperature Departure

                                          'Average Temperature Departure',
                                           rank_subset='first')



top_5_avg_temp_dep

                                          'Average Temperature Departure')



rank_avg_temp_dep

running_sum = analysis.running_sum(df,
                                   'Precipitation')



running_sum

                                     'Average Temperature')



running_mean

                                            'Average Temperature')



linear_detrend_avg_t

constant_detrend_avg_t = analysis.detrend_data(df,
                                            'Average Temperature',
                                              detrend_type='constant')



constant_detrend_avg_t

In this notebook, we downloaded xmACIS2 data and performed various types of statistical analyses on the data.

xmACIS2Py Documentation & Examples

xmACIS2Py Source Code Repository

Detrending Data (SciPy)

In this example, we will make a few graphics:

Comprehensive Temperature Summary for the past 30 days at KRAL.

Maximum Temperature Summary for July 2025 at KJFK.

Average Temperature Summary Detrended (Linear) from January 1st 1991 - December 31st 2020 at PASN.

Heating Degree Day Summary for December 2017 at KISP.

Cooling Degree Day Summary for July 2020 at KONT.

Growing Degree Summary for the past 180 days at KMIA

Precipitation Summary for December 2025 at KLAX

Graphical Summaries Documentation

Compreheisive Temperature Summary

Maximum Temperature Summary

Minimum Temperature Summary

Average Temperature Summary

Average Temperature Departure Summary

Heating Degree Day Summary

Cooling Degree Day Summary

Growing Degree Day Summary

Precipitation Summary

Concepts

Importance

Notes

xmACIS2Py

Necessary

xmACIS2Py Documentation

Intro to Pandas

Helpful

Familiarity with understanding dataframes

Intro to Matplotlib

Helpful

Familiarity with understanding graphics creation in Python

Time to learn: 45 minutes

---

Optional Arguments Used In This Example

Since it is currently winter, we will set cooling_degree_days=False to display a heating degree day summary rather than a cooling degree day summary.

temperature.plot_comprehensive_summary('kral',
                                      cooling_degree_days=False)

hierarchy.lvl3: Maximum Temperature Summary for July 2025 at KJFK.
Maximum Temperature Summary for July 2025 at KJFK.

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Maximum Temperature 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Maximum Temperature Summary July 2025’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

temperature.plot_maximum_temperature_summary('kjfk',
                                             product_type='Maximum Temperature Summary July 2025',
                                             start_date='2025-07-01',
                                             end_date='2025-07-31')

hierarchy.lvl3: Average Temperature Summary Detrended (Linear) from January 1st 1991 - December 31st 2020 at PANC.
Average Temperature Summary Detrended (Linear) from January 1st 1991 - December 31st 2020 at PANC.

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Average Temperature 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘30 Year Detrended Average Temperature PANC’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

Next, we will need to change our x_axis_day_interval.
The x_axis_day_interval is the interval in days the date/time displays on the x-axis.
The default x_axis_day_interval is 5 days so for a long time period, we want to make this interval 365 to get yearly x-ticks on the plot.

Next we will need to change x_axis_date_format.
The default x_axis_date_format is month/day (%m/%d). We want to change it to display years only (%Y).

Next we will need to set detrend_series=True to detrend this timeseries data. Default is detrend_series=False

Next we will set plot_type='line' since the default is plot_type='bar' and line graphs look better for longer timescales.

Next we will set show_running_mean=False (Default is show_running_mean=True) since the running mean might add some clutter to the image.

temperature.plot_average_temperature_summary('panc',
                                             product_type='30 Year Detrended Average Temperature PANC',
                                             start_date='1991-01-01',
                                             end_date='2020-12-31',
                                             x_axis_day_interval=365,
                                             x_axis_date_format='%Y',
                                             detrend_series=True,
                                             plot_type='line',
                                             show_running_mean=False)

hierarchy.lvl3: Heating Degree Day Summary for December 2017 at KISP
Heating Degree Day Summary for December 2017 at KISP

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Heating Degree Day 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Heating Degree Day Summary’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

Lastly, in this example we will show_running_mean=False (Default is show_running_mean=True) since the running mean might add some clutter to the image.

temperature.plot_heating_degree_day_summary('kisp',
                                            product_type='Heating Degree Day Summary',
                                            start_date='2017-12-01',
                                            end_date='2017-12-31',
                                            show_running_mean=False)

hierarchy.lvl3: Cooling Degree Day Summary for July 2020 at KONT
Cooling Degree Day Summary for July 2020 at KONT

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Cooling Degree Day 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Cooling Degree Day Summary’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

Lastly, in this example we will show_running_mean=False (Default is show_running_mean=True) since the running mean might add some clutter to the image.

temperature.plot_cooling_degree_day_summary('kont',
                                            product_type='Cooling Degree Day Summary',
                                            start_date='2020-07-01',
                                            end_date='2020-07-31',
                                            show_running_mean=False)

hierarchy.lvl3: Growing Degree Summary for the past 180 days at KMIA
Growing Degree Summary for the past 180 days at KMIA

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Growing Degree Day 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Growing Degree Day Summary’

Next we will need to change our time_delta from the default value of 30 days (time_delta=30) to 180 days (time_delta=180)

Next, we will need to change our x_axis_day_interval.
The x_axis_day_interval is the interval in days the date/time displays on the x-axis.
The default x_axis_day_interval is 5 days so for a longer time period, users will want to increase this interval to prevent x-ticks from being spaced too closely.
Here, we will set x_axis_day_interval=15 for a 15 day interval.

Lastly, in this example we will show_running_mean=False (Default is show_running_mean=True) since the running mean might add some clutter to the image.

temperature.plot_growing_degree_day_summary('kmia',
                                            product_type='Growing Degree Day Summary',
                                            time_delta=180,
                                            x_axis_day_interval=15,
                                            show_running_mean=False)

hierarchy.lvl3: Precipitation Summary for December 2025 at KLAX
Precipitation Summary for December 2025 at KLAX

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Precipitation 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Precipitation Summary’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

precipitation.plot_precipitation_summary('klax',
                                         product_type='Precipitation Summary',
                                         start_date='2025-12-01',
                                         end_date='2025-12-31')

hierarchy.lvl3: Precipitation Summary for December 2025 at KLAX With Running Sum
Precipitation Summary for December 2025 at KLAX With Running Sum

records.content:
Optional Arguments Used In This Example

We will want to change our product_type from the default of ‘Precipitation 30 Day Summary’ to better fit our analysis description.
Here, we will use ‘Precipitation Summary’

Next, we need to define our start_date and end_date to fit the period we want to analyze.
Date format is: YYYY-mm-dd

Since we want to display the running sum of precipitation this time, we will set show_running_sum=True.

precipitation.plot_precipitation_summary('klax',
                                         product_type='Precipitation Summary',
                                         start_date='2025-12-01',
                                         end_date='2025-12-31',
                                         show_running_sum=True)
In this notebook, we made various types of graphical summaries of temperature and precipitation data.
